Subject: Re: [neat] Welcoming the Era of Deep Neuroevolution
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=344770077; y=MsqW2FZU5e-vUGWOaXsdzXZNrQfp4E_B4l93ohwWeDJ_r42lQU2t
X-Yahoo-Profile: alienseedpod
From: Colin Green <colin.green1@...>


--f403043e3d186a11ac0560a47ab8
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="UTF-8"

Thanks Ken (and Jeff et al) for this interesting development.

A thought that comes to mind (having read the overview but not the
papers)...

As I recall from when I occasionally look int these things, the gradient
following methods out there generally use an /approximation/ of the
gradient, because it's computationally infeasible to calc the /true/
gradient, e.g. requiring the jacoban matrix, or with RBMs the true gradient
is given by iteratively bouncing activations between two adjacent layers,
which Hinton originally hand waved away as 'one or two iterations is good
enough!'.  It's possible (depending on the method) that the error between
the estimated and true gradient is systematically biased in unhelpful (i.e.
deceptive) ways, as opposed to the error being purely randomly distributed.
So I wonder then if adding randomness to these [possibly] biased gradient
approximations is partly overcoming a deceptive systematic bias. Or put
another way, if we could calc the true gradient then would adding
randomness to it still help? (not expecting an answer, just thinking out
loud).

Colin

--f403043e3d186a11ac0560a47ab8
Content-Type: text/html; charset="UTF-8"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
